fields:
Denary Number System

Number system that is made up of  {{c1::10 unique digits}}

Binary Number System

Number system that is made up of  {{c1::2 unique digits}}

Hexadecimal Number System

Number system that is made up of  {{c1::16 unique digits}}

Leading Zero

Zero digit (0) that is {{c1::to the left of the first non-zero digit}} in a number
Example: 00101001

Internet Protocol (IP) Address

{{c1::Sequence of bytes}} that is used to {{c1::identify a computer or device}} on {{c1::the Internet}}

Media Access Control (MAC) Address

{{c1::Sequence of bytes}} that is used to {{c1::identify}} a particular {{c1::network interface controller}}

Data Corruption

When data is made {{c1::unusable}} by {{c1::errors or alterations}}

Data Loss

When data is {{c1::destroyed and cannot be recovered}}

Backup

{{c1::Copy}} of data that is made in case the original is {{c1::damaged or lost}}

Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS)

Device that {{c1::provides enough emergency power}} for a computer to {{c1::properly shut down in case of a power failure}}

Authentication

Process of {{c1::verifying the identity of a user}}

Authentication Factor

{{c1::Category of evidence}} used for authentication, and is something {{c1::the user knows}}, something {{c1::the user owns}}, or something {{c1::that is measured from a physical part of the user}}

Examples:
  • Something the user knows: A password
  • Something the users owns: A phone
  • Something that is measured from a physical part of the user: Fingerprint

Unauthorised Access

Situation where {{c1::data owned by someone}} is {{c1::used by someone else}}, such as {{c1::an intruder}}, {{c1::without permission}}

Security Token

Device that is used specifically for {{c1::authentication purposes}}

Two-factor Authentication

Type of authentication that uses {{c1::evidence}} from both {{c1::something the user knows}} and {{c1::something the user owns}}

Biometrics

Type of authentication based on the {{c1::measurement of human physical characteristics}}

Identity Theft

{{c1::Impersonation}} of another person to {{c1::steal personal details}} such as {{c1::name and identity number}} for {{c1::fraudulent purposes}}

Authorisation/Access Control

Ability of a computer to control {{c1::a user’s access to data and resources}}

Permissions

Settings to {{c1::control the ability of users}} to {{c1::view or make changes to the contents of a file or folder}}

Administrator

{{c1::Special}} user who can {{c1::override the permissions}} for {{c1::almost any file or folder}}

Administrator Rights

Ability of a user to {{c1::perform tasks}} related to {{c1::authentication and authorisation}}, such as {{c1::creating and removing user accounts}}, {{c1::resetting passwords}} and {{c1::overriding file permissions}}

Firewall

Device or {{c1::computer program}} that {{c1::prevents unauthorised access to or from a private network}}

Traffic

{{c1::Transmission of data over a network}}

Intranet

{{c1::Private network}} that only {{c1::authorised users within an organisation can access}}

Application

{{c1::Software}} designed for users to {{c1::perform specific tasks}}

Encryption

Process of {{c1::encoding a message}} so that a {{c1::secret key}} is needed to {{c1::decode the data}}

Malicious Software/Malware

Software that is {{c1::intentionally used to damage, disrupt or gain unauthorised access}} to a computer system

Spamming

{{c1::Mass distribution}} of {{c1::unwanted messages or advertising}} to {{c1::email addresses}} which are collected from sources such as {{c1::public mailing lists, social networking sites, company websites and personal blogs}}

Anti-spyware/Anti-virus

Software to {{c1::detect, remove and stop}} spyware/viruses and other malware {{c1::from running}}

Operating System

Software designed to {{c1::support a computer’s basic functions}}

Signature (malware)

{{c1::Unique evidence}} that is used to {{c1::detect a known version}} of some malicious software

Copyright

The {{c1::legal right of owners}} to {{c1::control the use and distribution}} of their {{c1::intellectual property}}

Intellectual Property

{{c1::Creations of the mind}} that {{c1::have value}} but can exist {{c1::purely as data with no physical form}}

Copyright Infringement

{{c1::Use or distribution}} of {{c1::copyrighted work}} without {{c1::the permission of the copyright owner}}

Plagiarism

{{c1::Passing off someone else’s original work as one’s own}}

Licence

{{c1::Official description of activities}} that are {{c1::authorised or forbidden}} by the {{c1::owner of intellectual property}}

Software piracy

Crime of {{c1::copying, distributing and/or using proprietary software}} in a manner {{c1::that is not permitted by its licence}}

Free and Open-Source Software (FOSS)

Software where users are given {{c1::freedom to change, copy, study and share}} the software {{c1::and its source code}}

Public Domain Software

Software where {{c1::the legal protections that are typically granted to intellectual property}} have {{c1::either expired, been surrendered or are simply inapplicable}}

Freeware

{{c1::Proprietary}} software that is {{c1::available for use at no cost}}

Open Courseware

{{c1::Higher-education course materials}} such as {{c1::videos and notes created by universities}} and {{c1::distributed for free on the Internet}}

Proprietary Software

{{c1::Commercial}} software for which {{c1::most of the legal protections under copyright are retained}}

Shareware

{{c1::Demonstration}} software that {{c1::is distributed for free}} but {{c1::for a specific evaluation period only}}

Crack

Program that {{c1::modifies proprietary software}} so that the {{c1::software cannot detect that it is being used illegally}}

Cookie

A {{c1::small file}} used by {{c1::websites}} to {{c1::store personal information}} on a {{c1::user’s web browser}}

Pharming

The {{c1::interception of requests sent from a computer to a legitimate website and redirection to a fake website}} to {{c1::steal personal data or credit card details}}

Phishing

The {{c1::use of emails and fake websites that appear to be from reputable companies}} in order to {{c1::steal personal information such as passwords and credit card numbers from users}}

Spyware

A {{c1::hidden}} program that {{c1::secretly collects personal information about its users}} and {{c1::transmits this information to attackers without the users’ knowledge}}

Trojan Horse

A {{c1::computer program}} that {{c1::pretends to be a harmless file or useful application}}

Virus

A {{c1::computer program}} that {{c1::attaches itself to a normally harmless program and modifies it}}

When the {{c1::modified program is run by a user}}, the virus {{c1::attaches copies of itself to any other programs it can find}}, {{c1::thus “infecting” them}}

Worm

A computer program that {{c1::runs automatically}} and {{c1::attempts to spread by sending copies of itself to other computers}}

Unlike a virus, a worm {{c1::does not need to attach itself to an existing program}}

children.name: Unit 1.2 - Safe and Responsible Computer Use

fields:
Algorithm

{{c1::Set of step-by-step instructions for solving a problem}}

Input (algorithms)

Data {{c1::used by an algorithm}} that can {{c1::affect what is required for correct output}}

Output (algorithms)

{{c1::Results produced}} by an algorithm

Solution

{{c1::Algorithm}} that {{c1::always gives correct outputs}} when {{c1::provided with valid inputs}}

Sub-problem

A problem whose solution {{c1::contributes to the solution of a bigger problem}}

Decomposition

{{c1::Breaking down a complex problem into smaller and more manageable parts}}

Pattern Recognition

{{c1::Identifying similarities among two or more items}}

Generalisation

Technique of {{c1::replacing two or more similar problems or solution}} with a {{c1::single, more general problem or solution}}

Dry run

Process of {{c1::running through a set of steps manually}}

Test data

{{c1::Input data that is used to perform a dry run}}

Trace table

{{c1::Tabulation of the change in variables as well as the output of an algorithm}}

Pseudo-code

{{c1::Description of algorithm}} using {{c1::natural language}} mixed with {{c1::sequence, selection and iteration constructs}}

Instruction Set

Set of {{c1::basic commands or instructions}} that a {{c1::processor can understand directly}}, {{c1::represented in byte form}}

Program

{{c1::Set of instructions}} written to {{c1::perform specific tasks on a computer}}

Programming Language

Language designed for {{c1::humans to communicate instructions to computers}}

Source Code

{{c1::Instructions}} written in a {{c1::programming language that both humans and computers can understand}}

Syntax

{{c1::Rules that determine how the words and symbols in a valid instruction are arranged}}

Compiler

{{c1::Code translator}} program that {{c1::translates source code into machine code completely before running the compiled program}}

Interpreter

{{c1::Code translator}} program that {{c1::translates source code into machine code while the interpreted program is running}}

Type Casting

Process of {{c1::converting a value from one data type to another}}

Concatenation

{{c1::Joining two sequences to make a longer sequence}}

Control Flow Statement

{{c1::Programming instruction that changes the order in which other instructions are run}}
Example: Python if-elif-else statement

Test Case

{{c1::A set of inputs}} and {{c1::the corresponding set of expected outputs}} for a particular program used to {{c1::verify whether the program works as intended}}

Testing

{{c1::Process by which defects in a program can be detected}}

Module

{{c1::Collection of variables and functions that need to be loaded before they can be used}}

Character

{{c1::A unit of information for strings, usually a symbol, letter or digit.}}

Check Digit

{{c1::Digit or letter}} that is {{c1::added to a sequence of digits}} to {{c1::detect errors in manual input}}

Data Validation

Process of {{c1::ensuring that the input data supplied to a system}} satisfies {{c1::a set of rules}} such that {{c1::it is sensible, complete and within acceptable boundaries}}.

Length Check

Process of {{c1::ensuring that input data is not too short or too long}}

Range Check

Process of {{c1::ensuring that input data is within the required range of values}}

Presence Check

Process of {{c1::ensuring that all the required inputs are provided}}

Format Check

Process of {{c1::ensuring that input data matches a required arrangement or pattern}}

Crash

{{c1::Sudden stop of a program due to an error}}

Hang

{{c1::Unresponsiveness of a program due to an error}}

Run-time Error

Error that occurs {{c1::while the program is running}}

Logic Error

Error that {{c1::causes the output of a program to be different from what is expected}}

Syntax Error

Result of {{c1::incorrect source code that does not follow the rules of the language}}

Normal Conditions (programming)

Situations where {{c1::input data follows what is expected during normal use of the program}}

Boundary Conditions (programming)

Situations where {{c1::input data is at the limit of what the program is designed to cope with or where special handling is required}}

Error Conditions (programming)

Situations where {{c1::input data would normally be rejected by the program}}

Bug

{{c1::Defect in a program that causes it to behave in an unintended manner}}

Debugging

Process of {{c1::identifying and removing defects from a program}}

Machine Code

{{c1::Instructions}} that {{c1::can run directly on a computer’s processor}}

note_models.name: Cloze
